text:
Australia's quiet tree-lined suburban
streets maybe more than 13,000

kilometers away from Isis's
self-declared albeit crumbling Caliphate

but this is fertile ground for its
murderous ideology according to the

government
Isis has recruited around 200

Australians to fight in Iraq and Syria
including two friends of this young

Melbourne man I know two friends two
personal friends of mine who have

traveled to fight with Isis one is a
primary school friend and one is a

friend who a Sesenta gym a 20 year old
university student who are CNN not to

reveal his identity out of safety
concerns had no idea his friends were

being radicalized until they arrived in
Syria and while he didn't see any red

flags he believes a feeling of
alienation in their own country made

them vulnerable to Isis I do believe
that it's because of the lack of sense

of belonging here in Australia when they
when anybody travels overseas over there

were known as Australians here in
Australia where known as foreigners so

they're probably coming back thinking
who are we

authorities have managed to stop
hundreds of Australians from travelling

overseas to fight and those at home with
connections abroad other ones

experts say need to be watched in some
cases some ticking time bombs people who

who who sort of broken confused and
you've approached and and groomed by

those who want to use them could that
once again become dangerous just over a

week ago
Australia's security and intelligence

agencies for the most sophisticated
alleged terror plot ever seen in this

country to blow up a plane using an AED
and unleash a chemical bomb in a crowded

public space instructed by Isis it
hadn't been for the great work of our

intelligence agencies and law
enforcement over a very quick period of

time and we could very well have had a
catastrophic event in this country all

you have to do is put the press at him
all you have to do is believe a call for

lone wolf attacks has resonated with
homegrown jihadists leading to a spate

of them in Australia you can probably
hear the loud explosions behind me are

the most significant being the Sydney
siege in

2014 that led to three deaths including
the gunman while Australia has managed

to evade a major terrorist attack on
home soil experts say it's only a matter

of time
currently dozens of counter-terror

investigations are underway and at least
a thousand Australians with links to

terrorism unknown to police but it's
always flying under the radar that

analysts fear pose a real threat the
government has poured tens of millions

of dollars into de-radicalization
programs across the country that work

with communities and families to
identify early warning signs there are

not many mothers are going to dial a
hotline and dive in a song even if they

you know do with there's something wrong
but they may do something at that

grassroots level if they are connected
to people that they trust and confide in

but with Isis suffering defeats in Iraq
and Syria there's concern it will pull

out all stops to demonstrate it remains
a potent force that they could achieve a

sophisticated attack out of Sydney on
Auburn for them it would be a sign of

real potency a fear shared by this man
one of his friends has since been killed

on the battlefield the fate of the other
remains unknown but he's certain Isis

will continue to prey upon his community
we are not doing enough to stop it they

have nothing to lose we do Anna Coren
CNN Sydney
